14#ifndef DNS_RBT_H
15#define DNS_RBT_H 1

17/*! \file dns/rbt.h */
18
19#include <inttypes.h>
20#include <stdbool.h>
21
22#include <isc/assertions.h>
23#include <isc/crc64.h>
24#include <isc/lang.h>
25#include <isc/magic.h>
26#include <isc/refcount.h>
27
28#include <dns/types.h>
29
30ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
31
32/*@{*/
33/*%
34 * Option values for dns_rbt_findnode() and dns_rbt_findname().
35 * These are used to form a bitmask.
36 */
37#define DNS_RBTFIND_NOOPTIONS 0x00
38#define DNS_RBTFIND_EMPTYDATA 0x01
39#define DNS_RBTFIND_NOEXACT 0x02
40#define DNS_RBTFIND_NOPREDECESSOR 0x04
41/*@}*/
42
43#define DNS_RBT_USEMAGIC 1
44
45/*
46 * These should add up to 30.
47 */
48#define DNS_RBT_LOCKLENGTH 10
49#define DNS_RBT_REFLENGTH 20
50
51#define DNS_RBTNODE_MAGIC ISC_MAGIC('R','B','N','O')
52#if DNS_RBT_USEMAGIC
53#define DNS_RBTNODE_VALID(n) ISC_MAGIC_VALID(n, DNS_RBTNODE_MAGIC)
54#else
55#define DNS_RBTNODE_VALID(n) true
56#endif
57
58/*%
59 * This is the structure that is used for each node in the red/black
60 * tree of trees. NOTE WELL: the implementation manages this as a variable
61 * length structure, with the actual wire-format name and other data
62 * appended to this structure. Allocating a contiguous block of memory for
63 * multiple dns_rbtnode structures will not work.
64 */
65typedef struct dns_rbtnode dns_rbtnode_t;
66enum {
67 DNS_RBT_NSEC_NORMAL=0, /* in main tree */
68 DNS_RBT_NSEC_HAS_NSEC=1, /* also has node in nsec tree */
69 DNS_RBT_NSEC_NSEC=2, /* in nsec tree */
70 DNS_RBT_NSEC_NSEC3=3 /* in nsec3 tree */
71};
72struct dns_rbtnode {
73#if DNS_RBT_USEMAGIC
74 unsigned int magic;
75#endif
76 /*@{*/
77 /*!
78 * The following bitfields add up to a total bitwidth of 32.
79 * The range of values necessary for each item is indicated,
80 * but in the case of "attributes" the field is wider to accommodate
81 * possible future expansion.
82 *
83 * In each case below the "range" indicated is what's _necessary_ for
84 * the bitfield to hold, not what it actually _can_ hold.
85 *
86 * Note: Tree lock must be held before modifying these
87 * bit-fields.
88 *
89 * Note: The two "unsigned int :0;" unnamed bitfields on either
90 * side of the bitfields below are scaffolding that border the
91 * set of bitfields which are accessed after acquiring the tree
92 * lock. Please don't insert any other bitfield members between
93 * the unnamed bitfields unless they should also be accessed
94 * after acquiring the tree lock.
95 */
96 unsigned int :0; /* start of bitfields c/o tree lock */
97 unsigned int is_root : 1; /*%< range is 0..1 */
98 unsigned int color : 1; /*%< range is 0..1 */
99 unsigned int find_callback : 1; /*%< range is 0..1 */
100 unsigned int attributes : 3; /*%< range is 0..2 */
101 unsigned int nsec : 2; /*%< range is 0..3 */
102 unsigned int namelen : 8; /*%< range is 1..255 */
103 unsigned int offsetlen : 8; /*%< range is 1..128 */
104 unsigned int oldnamelen : 8; /*%< range is 1..255 */
105 /*@}*/
106
107 /* flags needed for serialization to file */
108 unsigned int is_mmapped : 1;
109 unsigned int parent_is_relative : 1;
110 unsigned int left_is_relative : 1;
111 unsigned int right_is_relative : 1;
112 unsigned int down_is_relative : 1;
113 unsigned int data_is_relative : 1;
114
115 /* node needs to be cleaned from rpz */
116 unsigned int rpz : 1;
117 unsigned int :0; /* end of bitfields c/o tree lock */
118
119 /*%
120 * These are needed for hashing. The 'uppernode' points to the
121 * node's superdomain node in the parent subtree, so that it can
122 * be reached from a child that was found by a hash lookup.
123 */
124 unsigned int hashval;
125 dns_rbtnode_t *uppernode;
126 dns_rbtnode_t *hashnext;
127
128 dns_rbtnode_t *parent;
129 dns_rbtnode_t *left;
130 dns_rbtnode_t *right;
131 dns_rbtnode_t *down;
132
133 /*%
134 * Used for LRU cache. This linked list is used to mark nodes which
135 * have no data any longer, but we cannot unlink at that exact moment
136 * because we did not or could not obtain a write lock on the tree.
137 */
138 ISC_LINK(dns_rbtnode_t) deadlink;
139
140 /*@{*/
141 /*!
142 * These values are used in the RBT DB implementation. The appropriate
143 * node lock must be held before accessing them.
144 *
145 * Note: The two "unsigned int :0;" unnamed bitfields on either
146 * side of the bitfields below are scaffolding that border the
147 * set of bitfields which are accessed after acquiring the node
148 * lock. Please don't insert any other bitfield members between
149 * the unnamed bitfields unless they should also be accessed
150 * after acquiring the node lock.
151 *
152 * NOTE: Do not merge these fields into bitfields above, as
153 * they'll all be put in the same qword that could be accessed
154 * without the node lock as it shares the qword with other
155 * members. Leave these members here so that they occupy a
156 * separate region of memory.
157 */
158 void *data;
159 unsigned int :0; /* start of bitfields c/o node lock */
160 unsigned int dirty:1;
161 unsigned int wild:1;
162 unsigned int locknum:DNS_RBT_LOCKLENGTH;
163 unsigned int :0; /* end of bitfields c/o node lock */
164 isc_refcount_t references; /* note that this is not in the bitfield */
165 /*@}*/
166};
167
168typedef isc_result_t (*dns_rbtfindcallback_t)(dns_rbtnode_t *node,
169 dns_name_t *name,
170 void *callback_arg);
171
172typedef isc_result_t (*dns_rbtdatawriter_t)(FILE *file,
173 unsigned char *data,
174 void *arg,
175 uint64_t *crc);
176
177typedef isc_result_t (*dns_rbtdatafixer_t)(dns_rbtnode_t *rbtnode,
178 void *base, size_t offset,
179 void *arg, uint64_t *crc);
180
181typedef void (*dns_rbtdeleter_t)(void *, void *);
182
183/*****
184 ***** Chain Info
185 *****/
186
187/*!
188 * A chain is used to keep track of the sequence of nodes to reach any given
189 * node from the root of the tree. Originally nodes did not have parent
190 * pointers in them (for memory usage reasons) so there was no way to find
191 * the path back to the root from any given node. Now that nodes have parent
192 * pointers, chains might be going away in a future release, though the
193 * movement functionality would remain.
194 *
195 * Chains may be used to iterate over a tree of trees. After setting up the
196 * chain's structure using dns_rbtnodechain_init(), it needs to be initialized
197 * to point to the lexically first or lexically last node in the tree of trees
198 * using dns_rbtnodechain_first() or dns_rbtnodechain_last(), respectively.
199 * Calling dns_rbtnodechain_next() or dns_rbtnodechain_prev() then moves the
200 * chain over to the next or previous node, respectively.
201 *
202 * In any event, parent information, whether via parent pointers or chains, is
203 * necessary information for iterating through the tree or for basic internal
204 * tree maintenance issues (ie, the rotations that are done to rebalance the
205 * tree when a node is added). The obvious implication of this is that for a
206 * chain to remain valid, the tree has to be locked down against writes for the
207 * duration of the useful life of the chain, because additions or removals can
208 * change the path from the root to the node the chain has targeted.
209 *
210 * The dns_rbtnodechain_ functions _first, _last, _prev and _next all take
211 * dns_name_t parameters for the name and the origin, which can be NULL. If
212 * non-NULL, 'name' will end up pointing to the name data and offsets that are
213 * stored at the node (and thus it will be read-only), so it should be a
214 * regular dns_name_t that has been initialized with dns_name_init. When
215 * 'origin' is non-NULL, it will get the name of the origin stored in it, so it
216 * needs to have its own buffer space and offsets, which is most easily
217 * accomplished with a dns_fixedname_t. It is _not_ necessary to reinitialize
218 * either 'name' or 'origin' between calls to the chain functions.
219 *
220 * NOTE WELL: even though the name data at the root of the tree of trees will
221 * be absolute (typically just "."), it will will be made into a relative name
222 * with an origin of "." -- an empty name when the node is ".". This is
223 * because a common on operation on 'name' and 'origin' is to use
224 * dns_name_concatenate() on them to generate the complete name. An empty name
225 * can be detected when dns_name_countlabels == 0, and is printed by
226 * dns_name_totext()/dns_name_format() as "@", consistent with RFC1035's
227 * definition of "@" as the current origin.
228 *
229 * dns_rbtnodechain_current is similar to the _first, _last, _prev and _next
230 * functions but additionally can provide the node to which the chain points.
231 */
232
233/*%
234 * The number of level blocks to allocate at a time. Currently the maximum
235 * number of levels is allocated directly in the structure, but future
236 * revisions of this code might have a static initial block with dynamic
237 * growth. Allocating space for 256 levels when the tree is almost never that
238 * deep is wasteful, but it's not clear that it matters, since the waste is
239 * only 2MB for 1000 concurrently active chains on a system with 64-bit
240 * pointers.
241 */
242#define DNS_RBT_LEVELBLOCK 254
243
244typedef struct dns_rbtnodechain {
245 unsigned int magic;
246 isc_mem_t * mctx;
247 /*%
248 * The terminal node of the chain. It is not in levels[].
249 * This is ostensibly private ... but in a pinch it could be
250 * used tell that the chain points nowhere without needing to
251 * call dns_rbtnodechain_current().
252 */
253 dns_rbtnode_t * end;
254 /*%
255 * The maximum number of labels in a name is 128; bitstrings mean
256 * a conceptually very large number (which I have not bothered to
257 * compute) of logical levels because splitting can potentially occur
258 * at each bit. However, DNSSEC restricts the number of "logical"
259 * labels in a name to 255, meaning only 254 pointers are needed
260 * in the worst case.
261 */
262 dns_rbtnode_t * levels[DNS_RBT_LEVELBLOCK];
263 /*%
264 * level_count indicates how deep the chain points into the
265 * tree of trees, and is the index into the levels[] array.
266 * Thus, levels[level_count - 1] is the last level node stored.
267 * A chain that points to the top level of the tree of trees has
268 * a level_count of 0, the first level has a level_count of 1, and
269 * so on.
270 */
271 unsigned int level_count;
272 /*%
273 * level_matches tells how many levels matched above the node
274 * returned by dns_rbt_findnode(). A match (partial or exact) found
275 * in the first level thus results in level_matches being set to 1.
276 * This is used by the rbtdb to set the start point for a recursive
277 * search of superdomains until the RR it is looking for is found.
278 */
279 unsigned int level_matches;
280} dns_rbtnodechain_t;
281
282/*****
283 ***** Public interfaces.
284 *****/
285isc_result_t
286dns_rbt_create(isc_mem_t *mctx, dns_rbtdeleter_t deleter,
287 void *deleter_arg, dns_rbt_t **rbtp);
288/*%<
289 * Initialize a red-black tree of trees.
290 *
291 * Notes:
292 *\li The deleter argument, if non-null, points to a function that is
293 * responsible for cleaning up any memory associated with the data
294 * pointer of a node when the node is deleted. It is passed the
295 * deleted node's data pointer as its first argument and deleter_arg
296 * as its second argument.
297 *
298 * Requires:
299 * \li mctx is a pointer to a valid memory context.
300 *\li rbtp != NULL && *rbtp == NULL
301 *\li arg == NULL iff deleter == NULL
302 *
303 * Ensures:
304 *\li If result is ISC_R_SUCCESS:
305 * *rbtp points to a valid red-black tree manager
306 *
307 *\li If result is failure:
308 * *rbtp does not point to a valid red-black tree manager.
309 *
310 * Returns:
311 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
312 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource limit: Out of Memory
313 */
314
315isc_result_t
316dns_rbt_addname(dns_rbt_t *rbt, const dns_name_t *name, void *data);
317/*%<
318 * Add 'name' to the tree of trees, associated with 'data'.
319 *
320 * Notes:
321 *\li 'data' is never required to be non-NULL, but specifying it
322 * when the name is added is faster than searching for 'name'
323 * again and then setting the data pointer. The lack of a data pointer
324 * for a node also has other ramifications regarding whether
325 * dns_rbt_findname considers a node to exist, or dns_rbt_deletename
326 * joins nodes.
327 *
328 * Requires:
329 *\li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
330 *\li dns_name_isabsolute(name) == TRUE
331 *
332 * Ensures:
333 *\li 'name' is not altered in any way.
334 *
335 *\li Any external references to nodes in the tree are unaffected by
336 * node splits that are necessary to insert the new name.
337 *
338 *\li If result is #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
339 * 'name' is findable in the red/black tree of trees in O(log N).
340 * The data pointer of the node for 'name' is set to 'data'.
341 *
342 *\li If result is #ISC_R_EXISTS or #ISC_R_NOSPACE:
343 * The tree of trees is unaltered.
344 *
345 *\li If result is #ISC_R_NOMEMORY:
346 * No guarantees.
347 *
348 * Returns:
349 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
350 *\li #ISC_R_EXISTS The name already exists with associated data.
351 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE The name had more logical labels than are allowed.
352 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource Limit: Out of Memory
353 */
354
355isc_result_t
356dns_rbt_addnode(dns_rbt_t *rbt, const dns_name_t *name, dns_rbtnode_t **nodep);
357
358/*%<
359 * Just like dns_rbt_addname, but returns the address of the node.
360 *
361 * Requires:
362 *\li rbt is a valid rbt structure.
363 *\li dns_name_isabsolute(name) == TRUE
364 *\li nodep != NULL && *nodep == NULL
365 *
366 * Ensures:
367 *\li 'name' is not altered in any way.
368 *
369 *\li Any external references to nodes in the tree are unaffected by
370 * node splits that are necessary to insert the new name.
371 *
372 *\li If result is ISC_R_SUCCESS:
373 * 'name' is findable in the red/black tree of trees in O(log N).
374 * *nodep is the node that was added for 'name'.
375 *
376 *\li If result is ISC_R_EXISTS:
377 * The tree of trees is unaltered.
378 * *nodep is the existing node for 'name'.
379 *
380 *\li If result is ISC_R_NOMEMORY:
381 * No guarantees.
382 *
383 * Returns:
384 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
385 *\li #ISC_R_EXISTS The name already exists, possibly without data.
386 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource Limit: Out of Memory
387 */
388
389isc_result_t
390dns_rbt_findname(dns_rbt_t *rbt, const dns_name_t *name, unsigned int options,
391 dns_name_t *foundname, void **data);
392/*%<
393 * Get the data pointer associated with 'name'.
394 *
395 * Notes:
396 *\li When #DNS_RBTFIND_NOEXACT is set, the closest matching superdomain is
397 * returned (also subject to #DNS_RBTFIND_EMPTYDATA), even when there is
398 * an exact match in the tree.
399 *
400 *\li A node that has no data is considered not to exist for this function,
401 * unless the #DNS_RBTFIND_EMPTYDATA option is set.
402 *
403 * Requires:
404 *\li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
405 *\li dns_name_isabsolute(name) == TRUE
406 *\li data != NULL && *data == NULL
407 *
408 * Ensures:
409 *\li 'name' and the tree are not altered in any way.
410 *
411 *\li If result is ISC_R_SUCCESS:
412 * *data is the data associated with 'name'.
413 *
414 *\li If result is DNS_R_PARTIALMATCH:
415 * *data is the data associated with the deepest superdomain
416 * of 'name' which has data.
417 *
418 *\li If result is ISC_R_NOTFOUND:
419 * Neither the name nor a superdomain was found with data.
420 *
421 * Returns:
422 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
423 *\li #DNS_R_PARTIALMATCH Superdomain found with data
424 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND No match
425 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE Concatenating nodes to form foundname failed
426 */
427
428isc_result_t
429dns_rbt_findnode(dns_rbt_t *rbt, const dns_name_t *name, dns_name_t *foundname,
430 dns_rbtnode_t **node, dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain,
431 unsigned int options, dns_rbtfindcallback_t callback,
432 void *callback_arg);
433/*%<
434 * Find the node for 'name'.
435 *
436 * Notes:
437 *\li A node that has no data is considered not to exist for this function,
438 * unless the DNS_RBTFIND_EMPTYDATA option is set. This applies to both
439 * exact matches and partial matches.
440 *
441 *\li If the chain parameter is non-NULL, then the path through the tree
442 * to the DNSSEC predecessor of the searched for name is maintained,
443 * unless the DNS_RBTFIND_NOPREDECESSOR or DNS_RBTFIND_NOEXACT option
444 * is used. (For more details on those options, see below.)
445 *
446 *\li If there is no predecessor, then the chain will point to nowhere, as
447 * indicated by chain->end being NULL or dns_rbtnodechain_current
448 * returning ISC_R_NOTFOUND. Note that in a normal Internet DNS RBT
449 * there will always be a predecessor for all names except the root
450 * name, because '.' will exist and '.' is the predecessor of
451 * everything. But you can certainly construct a trivial tree and a
452 * search for it that has no predecessor.
453 *
454 *\li Within the chain structure, the 'levels' member of the structure holds
455 * the root node of each level except the first.
456 *
457 *\li The 'level_count' of the chain indicates how deep the chain to the
458 * predecessor name is, as an index into the 'levels[]' array. It does
459 * not count name elements, per se, but only levels of the tree of trees,
460 * the distinction arising because multiple labels from a name can be
461 * stored on only one level. It is also does not include the level
462 * that has the node, since that level is not stored in levels[].
463 *
464 *\li The chain's 'level_matches' is not directly related to the predecessor.
465 * It is the number of levels above the level of the found 'node',
466 * regardless of whether it was a partial match or exact match. When
467 * the node is found in the top level tree, or no node is found at all,
468 * level_matches is 0.
469 *
470 *\li When DNS_RBTFIND_NOEXACT is set, the closest matching superdomain is
471 * returned (also subject to DNS_RBTFIND_EMPTYDATA), even when
472 * there is an exact match in the tree. In this case, the chain
473 * will not point to the DNSSEC predecessor, but will instead point
474 * to the exact match, if there was any. Thus the preceding paragraphs
475 * should have "exact match" substituted for "predecessor" to describe
476 * how the various elements of the chain are set. This was done to
477 * ensure that the chain's state was sane, and to prevent problems that
478 * occurred when running the predecessor location code under conditions
479 * it was not designed for. It is not clear *where* the chain should
480 * point when DNS_RBTFIND_NOEXACT is set, so if you end up using a chain
481 * with this option because you want a particular node, let us know
482 * where you want the chain pointed, so this can be made more firm.
483 *
484 * Requires:
485 *\li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
486 *\li dns_name_isabsolute(name) == TRUE.
487 *\li node != NULL && *node == NULL.
488 *\li #DNS_RBTFIND_NOEXACT and DNS_RBTFIND_NOPREDECESSOR are mutually
489 * exclusive.
490 *
491 * Ensures:
492 *\li 'name' and the tree are not altered in any way.
493 *
494 *\li If result is ISC_R_SUCCESS:
495 *\verbatim
496 * *node is the terminal node for 'name'.
497
498 * 'foundname' and 'name' represent the same name (though not
499 * the same memory).
500
501 * 'chain' points to the DNSSEC predecessor, if any, of 'name'.
502 *
503 * chain->level_matches and chain->level_count are equal.
504 *\endverbatim
505 *
506 * If result is DNS_R_PARTIALMATCH:
507 *\verbatim
508 * *node is the data associated with the deepest superdomain
509 * of 'name' which has data.
510 *
511 * 'foundname' is the name of deepest superdomain (which has
512 * data, unless the DNS_RBTFIND_EMPTYDATA option is set).
513 *
514 * 'chain' points to the DNSSEC predecessor, if any, of 'name'.
515 *\endverbatim
516 *
517 *\li If result is ISC_R_NOTFOUND:
518 *\verbatim
519 * Neither the name nor a superdomain was found. *node is NULL.
520 *
521 * 'chain' points to the DNSSEC predecessor, if any, of 'name'.
522 *
523 * chain->level_matches is 0.
524 *\endverbatim
525 *
526 * Returns:
527 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
528 *\li #DNS_R_PARTIALMATCH Superdomain found with data
529 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND No match, or superdomain with no data
530 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE Concatenating nodes to form foundname failed
531 */
532
533isc_result_t
534dns_rbt_deletename(dns_rbt_t *rbt, const dns_name_t *name,
535 bool recurse);
536/*%<
537 * Delete 'name' from the tree of trees.
538 *
539 * Notes:
540 *\li When 'name' is removed, if recurse is true then all of its
541 * subnames are removed too.
542 *
543 * Requires:
544 *\li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
545 *\li dns_name_isabsolute(name) == TRUE
546 *
547 * Ensures:
548 *\li 'name' is not altered in any way.
549 *
550 *\li Does NOT ensure that any external references to nodes in the tree
551 * are unaffected by node joins.
552 *
553 *\li If result is ISC_R_SUCCESS:
554 * 'name' does not appear in the tree with data; however,
555 * the node for the name might still exist which can be
556 * found with dns_rbt_findnode (but not dns_rbt_findname).
557 *
558 *\li If result is ISC_R_NOTFOUND:
559 * 'name' does not appear in the tree with data, because
560 * it did not appear in the tree before the function was called.
561 *
562 *\li If result is something else:
563 * See result codes for dns_rbt_findnode (if it fails, the
564 * node is not deleted) or dns_rbt_deletenode (if it fails,
565 * the node is deleted, but the tree is not optimized when
566 * it could have been).
567 *
568 * Returns:
569 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
570 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND No match
571 *\li something_else Any return code from dns_rbt_findnode except
572 * DNS_R_PARTIALMATCH (which causes ISC_R_NOTFOUND
573 * to be returned instead), and any code from
574 * dns_rbt_deletenode.
575 */
576
577isc_result_t
578dns_rbt_deletenode(dns_rbt_t *rbt, dns_rbtnode_t *node, bool recurse);
579/*%<
580 * Delete 'node' from the tree of trees.
581 *
582 * Notes:
583 *\li When 'node' is removed, if recurse is true then all nodes
584 * in levels down from it are removed too.
585 *
586 * Requires:
587 *\li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
588 *\li node != NULL.
589 *
590 * Ensures:
591 *\li Does NOT ensure that any external references to nodes in the tree
592 * are unaffected by node joins.
593 *
594 *\li If result is ISC_R_SUCCESS:
595 * 'node' does not appear in the tree with data; however,
596 * the node might still exist if it serves as a pointer to
597 * a lower tree level as long as 'recurse' was false, hence
598 * the node could can be found with dns_rbt_findnode when
599 * that function's empty_data_ok parameter is true.
600 *
601 *\li If result is ISC_R_NOMEMORY or ISC_R_NOSPACE:
602 * The node was deleted, but the tree structure was not
603 * optimized.
604 *
605 * Returns:
606 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success
607 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource Limit: Out of Memory when joining nodes.
608 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE dns_name_concatenate failed when joining nodes.
609 */
610
611void
612dns_rbt_namefromnode(dns_rbtnode_t *node, dns_name_t *name);
613/*%<
614 * Convert the sequence of labels stored at 'node' into a 'name'.
615 *
616 * Notes:
617 *\li This function does not return the full name, from the root, but
618 * just the labels at the indicated node.
619 *
620 *\li The name data pointed to by 'name' is the information stored
621 * in the node, not a copy. Altering the data at this pointer
622 * will likely cause grief.
623 *
624 * Requires:
625 * \li name->offsets == NULL
626 *
627 * Ensures:
628 * \li 'name' is DNS_NAMEATTR_READONLY.
629 *
630 * \li 'name' will point directly to the labels stored after the
631 * dns_rbtnode_t struct.
632 *
633 * \li 'name' will have offsets that also point to the information stored
634 * as part of the node.
635 */
636
637isc_result_t
638dns_rbt_fullnamefromnode(dns_rbtnode_t *node, dns_name_t *name);
639/*%<
640 * Like dns_rbt_namefromnode, but returns the full name from the root.
641 *
642 * Notes:
643 * \li Unlike dns_rbt_namefromnode, the name will not point directly
644 * to node data. Rather, dns_name_concatenate will be used to copy
645 * the name data from each node into the 'name' argument.
646 *
647 * Requires:
648 * \li name != NULL
649 * \li name has a dedicated buffer.
650 *
651 * Returns:
652 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
653 * \li ISC_R_NOSPACE (possible via dns_name_concatenate)
654 * \li DNS_R_NAMETOOLONG (possible via dns_name_concatenate)
655 */
656
657char *
658dns_rbt_formatnodename(dns_rbtnode_t *node, char *printname,
659 unsigned int size);
660/*%<
661 * Format the full name of a node for printing, using dns_name_format().
662 *
663 * Notes:
664 * \li 'size' is the length of the printname buffer. This should be
665 * DNS_NAME_FORMATSIZE or larger.
666 *
667 * Requires:
668 * \li node and printname are not NULL.
669 *
670 * Returns:
671 * \li The 'printname' pointer.
672 */
673
674unsigned int
675dns_rbt_nodecount(dns_rbt_t *rbt);
676/*%<
677 * Obtain the number of nodes in the tree of trees.
678 *
679 * Requires:
680 * \li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
681 */
682
683size_t
684dns_rbt_hashsize(dns_rbt_t *rbt);
685/*%<
686 * Obtain the current number of buckets in the 'rbt' hash table.
687 *
688 * Requires:
689 * \li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
690 */
691
692void
693dns_rbt_destroy(dns_rbt_t **rbtp);
694isc_result_t
695dns_rbt_destroy2(dns_rbt_t **rbtp, unsigned int quantum);
696/*%<
697 * Stop working with a red-black tree of trees.
698 * If 'quantum' is zero then the entire tree will be destroyed.
699 * If 'quantum' is non zero then up to 'quantum' nodes will be destroyed
700 * allowing the rbt to be incrementally destroyed by repeated calls to
701 * dns_rbt_destroy2(). Once dns_rbt_destroy2() has been called no other
702 * operations than dns_rbt_destroy()/dns_rbt_destroy2() should be
703 * performed on the tree of trees.
704 *
705 * Requires:
706 * \li *rbt is a valid rbt manager.
707 *
708 * Ensures on ISC_R_SUCCESS:
709 * \li All space allocated by the RBT library has been returned.
710 *
711 * \li *rbt is invalidated as an rbt manager.
712 *
713 * Returns:
714 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
715 * \li ISC_R_QUOTA if 'quantum' nodes have been destroyed.
716 */
717
718off_t
719dns_rbt_serialize_align(off_t target);
720/*%<
721 * Align the provided integer to a pointer-size boundary.
722 * This should be used if, during serialization of data to a will-be
723 * mmap()ed file, a pointer alignment is needed for some data.
724 */
725
726isc_result_t
727dns_rbt_serialize_tree(FILE *file, dns_rbt_t *rbt,
728 dns_rbtdatawriter_t datawriter,
729 void *writer_arg, off_t *offset);
730/*%<
731 * Write out the RBT structure and its data to a file.
732 *
733 * Notes:
734 * \li The file must be an actual file which allows seek() calls, so it cannot
735 * be a stream. Returns ISC_R_INVALIDFILE if not.
736 */
737
738isc_result_t
739dns_rbt_deserialize_tree(void *base_address, size_t filesize,
740 off_t header_offset, isc_mem_t *mctx,
741 dns_rbtdeleter_t deleter, void *deleter_arg,
742 dns_rbtdatafixer_t datafixer, void *fixer_arg,
743 dns_rbtnode_t **originp, dns_rbt_t **rbtp);
744/*%<
745 * Read a RBT structure and its data from a file.
746 *
747 * If 'originp' is not NULL, then it is pointed to the root node of the RBT.
748 *
749 * Notes:
750 * \li The file must be an actual file which allows seek() calls, so it cannot
751 * be a stream. This condition is not checked in the code.
752 */
753
754void
755dns_rbt_printtext(dns_rbt_t *rbt,
756 void (*data_printer)(FILE *, void *), FILE *f);
757/*%<
758 * Print an ASCII representation of the internal structure of the red-black
759 * tree of trees to the passed stream.
760 *
761 * data_printer is a callback function that is called to print the data
762 * in a node. It should print it to the passed FILE stream.
763 *
764 * Notes:
765 * \li The name stored at each node, along with the node's color, is printed.
766 * Then the down pointer, left and right pointers are displayed
767 * recursively in turn. NULL down pointers are silently omitted;
768 * NULL left and right pointers are printed.
769 */
770
771void
772dns_rbt_printdot(dns_rbt_t *rbt, bool show_pointers, FILE *f);
773/*%<
774 * Print a GraphViz dot representation of the internal structure of the
775 * red-black tree of trees to the passed stream.
776 *
777 * If show_pointers is TRUE, pointers are also included in the generated
778 * graph.
779 *
780 * Notes:
781 * \li The name stored at each node, along with the node's color is displayed.
782 * Then the down pointer, left and right pointers are displayed
783 * recursively in turn. NULL left, right and down pointers are
784 * silently omitted.
785 */
786
787void
788dns_rbt_printnodeinfo(dns_rbtnode_t *n, FILE *f);
789/*%<
790 * Print out various information about a node
791 *
792 * Requires:
793 *\li 'n' is a valid pointer.
794 *
795 *\li 'f' points to a valid open FILE structure that allows writing.
796 */
797
798
799size_t
800dns__rbt_getheight(dns_rbt_t *rbt);
801/*%<
802 * Return the maximum height of sub-root nodes found in the red-black
803 * forest.
804 *
805 * The height of a node is defined as the number of nodes in the longest
806 * path from the node to a leaf. For each subtree in the forest, this
807 * function determines the height of its root node. Then it returns the
808 * maximum such height in the forest.
809 *
810 * Note: This function exists for testing purposes. Non-test code must
811 * not use it.
812 *
813 * Requires:
814 * \li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
815 */
816
817bool
818dns__rbt_checkproperties(dns_rbt_t *rbt);
819/*%<
820 * Check red-black properties of the forest.
821 *
822 * Note: This function exists for testing purposes. Non-test code must
823 * not use it.
824 *
825 * Requires:
826 * \li rbt is a valid rbt manager.
827 */
828
829size_t
830dns__rbtnode_getdistance(dns_rbtnode_t *node);
831/*%<
832 * Return the distance (in nodes) from the node to its upper node of its
833 * subtree. The root node has a distance of 1. A child of the root node
834 * has a distance of 2.
835 */
836
837/*****
838 ***** Chain Functions
839 *****/
840
841void
842dns_rbtnodechain_init(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, isc_mem_t *mctx);
843/*%<
844 * Initialize 'chain'.
845 *
846 * Requires:
847 *\li 'chain' is a valid pointer.
848 *
849 *\li 'mctx' is a valid memory context.
850 *
851 * Ensures:
852 *\li 'chain' is suitable for use.
853 */
854
855void
856dns_rbtnodechain_reset(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain);
857/*%<
858 * Free any dynamic storage associated with 'chain', and then reinitialize
859 * 'chain'.
860 *
861 * Requires:
862 *\li 'chain' is a valid pointer.
863 *
864 * Ensures:
865 *\li 'chain' is suitable for use, and uses no dynamic storage.
866 */
867
868void
869dns_rbtnodechain_invalidate(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain);
870/*%<
871 * Free any dynamic storage associated with 'chain', and then invalidates it.
872 *
873 * Notes:
874 *\li Future calls to any dns_rbtnodechain_ function will need to call
875 * dns_rbtnodechain_init on the chain first (except, of course,
876 * dns_rbtnodechain_init itself).
877 *
878 * Requires:
879 *\li 'chain' is a valid chain.
880 *
881 * Ensures:
882 *\li 'chain' is no longer suitable for use, and uses no dynamic storage.
883 */
884
885isc_result_t
886dns_rbtnodechain_current(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, dns_name_t *name,
887 dns_name_t *origin, dns_rbtnode_t **node);
888/*%<
889 * Provide the name, origin and node to which the chain is currently pointed.
890 *
891 * Notes:
892 *\li The tree need not have be locked against additions for the chain
893 * to remain valid, however there are no guarantees if any deletion
894 * has been made since the chain was established.
895 *
896 * Requires:
897 *\li 'chain' is a valid chain.
898 *
899 * Ensures:
900 *\li 'node', if non-NULL, is the node to which the chain was pointed
901 * by dns_rbt_findnode, dns_rbtnodechain_first or dns_rbtnodechain_last.
902 * If none were called for the chain since it was initialized or reset,
903 * or if the was no predecessor to the name searched for with
904 * dns_rbt_findnode, then '*node' is NULL and ISC_R_NOTFOUND is returned.
905 *
906 *\li 'name', if non-NULL, is the name stored at the terminal level of
907 * the chain. This is typically a single label, like the "www" of
908 * "www.isc.org", but need not be so. At the root of the tree of trees,
909 * if the node is "." then 'name' is ".", otherwise it is relative to ".".
910 * (Minimalist and atypical case: if the tree has just the name
911 * "isc.org." then the root node's stored name is "isc.org." but 'name'
912 * will be "isc.org".)
913 *
914 *\li 'origin', if non-NULL, is the sequence of labels in the levels
915 * above the terminal level, such as "isc.org." in the above example.
916 * 'origin' is always "." for the root node.
917 *
918 *
919 * Returns:
920 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS name, origin & node were successfully set.
921 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND The chain does not point to any node.
922 *\li &lt;something_else> Any error return from dns_name_concatenate.
923 */
924
925isc_result_t
926dns_rbtnodechain_first(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, dns_rbt_t *rbt,
927 dns_name_t *name, dns_name_t *origin);
928/*%<
929 * Set the chain to the lexically first node in the tree of trees.
930 *
931 * Notes:
932 *\li By the definition of ordering for DNS names, the root of the tree of
933 * trees is the very first node, since everything else in the megatree
934 * uses it as a common suffix.
935 *
936 * Requires:
937 *\li 'chain' is a valid chain.
938 *\li 'rbt' is a valid rbt manager.
939 *
940 * Ensures:
941 *\li The chain points to the very first node of the tree.
942 *
943 *\li 'name' and 'origin', if non-NULL, are set as described for
944 * dns_rbtnodechain_current. Thus 'origin' will always be ".".
945 *
946 * Returns:
947 *\li #DNS_R_NEWORIGIN The name & origin were successfully set.
948 *\li &lt;something_else> Any error result from dns_rbtnodechain_current.
949 */
950
951isc_result_t
952dns_rbtnodechain_last(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, dns_rbt_t *rbt,
953 dns_name_t *name, dns_name_t *origin);
954/*%<
955 * Set the chain to the lexically last node in the tree of trees.
956 *
957 * Requires:
958 *\li 'chain' is a valid chain.
959 *\li 'rbt' is a valid rbt manager.
960 *
961 * Ensures:
962 *\li The chain points to the very last node of the tree.
963 *
964 *\li 'name' and 'origin', if non-NULL, are set as described for
965 * dns_rbtnodechain_current.
966 *
967 * Returns:
968 *\li #DNS_R_NEWORIGIN The name & origin were successfully set.
969 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY Resource Limit: Out of Memory building chain.
970 *\li &lt;something_else> Any error result from dns_name_concatenate.
971 */
972
973isc_result_t
974dns_rbtnodechain_prev(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, dns_name_t *name,
975 dns_name_t *origin);
976/*%<
977 * Adjusts chain to point the DNSSEC predecessor of the name to which it
978 * is currently pointed.
979 *
980 * Requires:
981 *\li 'chain' is a valid chain.
982 *\li 'chain' has been pointed somewhere in the tree with dns_rbt_findnode,
983 * dns_rbtnodechain_first or dns_rbtnodechain_last -- and remember that
984 * dns_rbt_findnode is not guaranteed to point the chain somewhere,
985 * since there may have been no predecessor to the searched for name.
986 *
987 * Ensures:
988 *\li The chain is pointed to the predecessor of its current target.
989 *
990 *\li 'name' and 'origin', if non-NULL, are set as described for
991 * dns_rbtnodechain_current.
992 *
993 *\li 'origin' is only if a new origin was found.
994 *
995 * Returns:
996 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS The predecessor was found and 'name' was set.
997 *\li #DNS_R_NEWORIGIN The predecessor was found with a different
998 * origin and 'name' and 'origin' were set.
999 *\li #ISC_R_NOMORE There was no predecessor.
1000 *\li &lt;something_else> Any error result from dns_rbtnodechain_current.
1001 */
1002
1003isc_result_t
1004dns_rbtnodechain_next(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, dns_name_t *name,
1005 dns_name_t *origin);
1006/*%<
1007 * Adjusts chain to point the DNSSEC successor of the name to which it
1008 * is currently pointed.
1009 *
1010 * Requires:
1011 *\li 'chain' is a valid chain.
1012 *\li 'chain' has been pointed somewhere in the tree with dns_rbt_findnode,
1013 * dns_rbtnodechain_first or dns_rbtnodechain_last -- and remember that
1014 * dns_rbt_findnode is not guaranteed to point the chain somewhere,
1015 * since there may have been no predecessor to the searched for name.
1016 *
1017 * Ensures:
1018 *\li The chain is pointed to the successor of its current target.
1019 *
1020 *\li 'name' and 'origin', if non-NULL, are set as described for
1021 * dns_rbtnodechain_current.
1022 *
1023 *\li 'origin' is only if a new origin was found.
1024 *
1025 * Returns:
1026 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS The successor was found and 'name' was set.
1027 *\li #DNS_R_NEWORIGIN The successor was found with a different
1028 * origin and 'name' and 'origin' were set.
1029 *\li #ISC_R_NOMORE There was no successor.
1030 *\li &lt;something_else> Any error result from dns_name_concatenate.
1031 */
1032
1033isc_result_t
1034dns_rbtnodechain_down(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, dns_name_t *name,
1035 dns_name_t *origin);
1036/*%<
1037 * Descend down if possible.
1038 */
1039
1040isc_result_t
1041dns_rbtnodechain_nextflat(dns_rbtnodechain_t *chain, dns_name_t *name);
1042/*%<
1043 * Find the next node at the current depth in DNSSEC order.
1044 */
1045
1046void
1047dns_rbtnode_nodename(dns_rbtnode_t *node, dns_name_t *name);
1048
1049dns_rbtnode_t *
1050dns_rbt_root(dns_rbt_t *rbt);
1051
1052ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
1053
1054#endif /* DNS_RBT_H */
